key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris visited NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center to focus on climate science.
NASA Administrator Bill Nelson presented first images from Landsat 9, highlighting environmental changes.
Landsat 9's images, taken on Oct. 31, show significant locations and contribute to nearly 50 years of Earth observation.
Harris emphasized the extensive potential of space activity in climate action, education, economic growth, innovation, inspiration, security, and strength.
A new Earth Venture Mission-3 (EVM-3), named INCUS, was discussed, aiming to improve understanding of storm development.
The Biden-Harris Administration's commitment to addressing the climate crisis was underscored.
Climate data from NASA, NOAA, and USGS is crucial for understanding extreme weather and climate events.
Harris met with scientists and engineers to discuss NASA's role in tackling climate challenges.
NOAA Administrator Rick Spinrad highlighted the NOAA-NASA partnership's contributions to climate and weather monitoring.
Harris operated a robotic arm for future Landsat 7 missions and visited the under-construction PACE mission for ocean health assessment.
spokespersons: Tanya Trujillo (Assistant Secretary for Water and Science, Department of the Interior)
